pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces the very basic definitions of degenerate and non degenerate simplices.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ae68db8523](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21098/commits/ae68db85239ea31e1a7b851aa77731c6f2f0ebf0)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.AlgebraicTopology.SimplicialSet.Degenerate` (new file)|864|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ degenerate`
`+ degenerate_eq_iUnion_range_σ`
`+ degenerate_zero`
`+ exists_nonDegenerate`
`+ isIso_of_nonDegenerate`
`+ mem_degenerate_iff`
`+ mem_degenerate_iff_not_mem_nonDegenerate`
`+ mem_nonDegenerate_iff_not_mem_degenerate`
`+ nonDegenerate`
`+ nondegenerate_zero`
`+ σ_mem_degenerate`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

```suggestion
/-- An `n`-simplex of a simplicial set `X` is degenerate if it is in the range
```
I'm not actually certain if "an `n`-simplex" or "a `n`-simplex" is correct, but some primitive grepping suggests that the string "an \`n\`-" is far more common in mathlib than the string "a \`n\`-".

Not blocking, but I'm curious what the convention is for taking inputs in the `SimplexCategory`. i.e., when should we use `(m : ℕ) (f : [n] ⟶ [m])` vs. `(m : SimplexCategory) (f : [n] ⟶ m)`?

This has some small implications for pretty-printing these notations, but otherwise it seems to me that any convention is just as good here.

In this particular case, as there is an inequality, I thought it was more convenient to write it as `m < n` rather than `m.len < n`. It does not matter here as this is part of the internals of the API and I provide some lemmas like `degenerate_eq_iUnion_range_σ` which gives more explicit characterizations. Otherwise, for general definitions and lemmas, if it makes sense for `m : SimplexCategory`, it is advisable to use `SimplexCategory` rather than `ℕ`.

For example, below, for `isIso_of_nonDegenerate`, I have used `m : SimplexCategory` and shown that `f : [n]  ⟶ m` was an isomorphisms, which allows to show that `m` is equal to `[n]`, and then `f` is actually the identity of `[n]`.

That's helpful, thanks. I suppose `m : SimplexCategory` is strictly more general since the term need not be of the form `SimplexCategory.mk _`.

Incidentally, `m.len` cannot be typed in a subscript. You can write `[n]₍ₗₑₙ ₘ₎`, but this only happens to work because all of the letters involved can be subscripted. One can always fall back to writing out the term where the notation falls down, but do you think it would be worth revisiting the choice of subscripts for this notation while the brackets are in question?
I would think that in most applications, the subscript will be a litteral 1-digit natural number, no?

Yes, my assumption (and experience so far) is that `[m]ₙ₊₁` is about as complex an expression as we would need for the truncation level. If that seems reasonable, I think I will avoid further cluttering the notation discussion with subscript questions.

pullRequest.title: feat(AlgebraicTopology/SimplicialSet): degenerate simplices

source.title: feat(AlgebraicTopology/SimplicialSet): uniqueness of the decomposition involving non-degenerate simplices
